title: (x) Balance Books logo serif - Mrs Eaves {Tiff}
content:
FedraSerifB book is close but the bottom lobe on the logo is different.  
I’m looking to ID the top ’B’  
Thanks!

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080105062627im_/http:/typophile.com/files/font_id_4792.gif)

 [‹ (x) Thin "Free Free Super Music Maker" geometric sans - Futura (customized) {Yves}](http://web.archive.org/web/20080105062627/http:/typophile.com/node/40499 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) Curvy 60s display sans - Roberta {Mike F} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080105062627/http:/typophile.com/node/40480 "Go to next forum topic")
author: link

comments.content: Is the logo you are talking about formed by one only ’B’ ?

Attaching the actual logo. I found the other letters are too small and fuzzy to ID.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080105062627im_/http:/typophile.com/files/logo_crop_3515.gif)

<cite>I found the other letters are too small and fuzzy to ID.</cite>

The ‘C’ says Baskerville. Some Caslons have that one, too.  
 [Have a look yourself.](http://web.archive.org/web/20080105062627/http:/www.fontshop.com/search/?q=baskerville&site=d&sample_text=B&sample_size=388)  
F
You’re amazing! Perfect! Thank you so much.
That looks like Mrs. Eaves to me.

Link, could you please explain why you singled out the B and didn’t show us the complete logo? Frankly you made our lives quite a bit harder. ;^)

It is imperative for an identification that you provide us with as much information as possible. Trying to identify a typeface from a single letter is one of the hardest things to do, especially when it’s a less typical character like a capital B.
